Pros_x: Awesome formal training before it opened, tipped out, decent hours at beginning.
Cons_x: After a few months of working, they decided to hire new people, so many employees (and myself) had hours cut back.
Advice to Management_x: My managers definitely played favorites, unfortunately. That shouldn't be happening.
Pros_y: Great brand, awesome name recognition. Fantastic product albeit a liitle over-priced for the ambiance. They like to compare themselves to other chain restaurants like Cheesecake Factory and PF Changs but their facitlities lack the correct ambiance for its price point.
Cons_y: Unrealistic financial expectations that are applied uniformly to all locations and regions in the US. Average work week is 55-60 hours per week which is fine but you always expected to work form home or on your days off. External marketing is expected to happen largely at the store level without more labor dollars offered to cover your absence in the store.
Advice to Management_y: Get back in touch with what it means to run a restaurant from an operations point of view for the last 5 years with the huge economic downturn our country has been facing and then ask for my help to turn it around. Its not the same as when you were operators.

Pros_y: Great brand, awesome name recognition. Fantastic product albeit a liitle over-priced for the ambiance. They like to compare themselves to other chain restaurants like Cheesecake Factory and PF Changs but their facitlities lack the correct ambiance for its price point.
Cons_y: Unrealistic financial expectations that are applied uniformly to all locations and regions in the US. Average work week is 55-60 hours per week which is fine but you always expected to work form home or on your days off. External marketing is expected to happen largely at the store level without more labor dollars offered to cover your absence in the store.
Advice to Management_y: Get back in touch with what it means to run a restaurant from an operations point of view for the last 5 years with the huge economic downturn our country has been facing and then ask for my help to turn it around. Its not the same as when you were operators.

Pros_y: Great brand, awesome name recognition. Fantastic product albeit a liitle over-priced for the ambiance. They like to compare themselves to other chain restaurants like Cheesecake Factory and PF Changs but their facitlities lack the correct ambiance for its price point.
Cons_y: Unrealistic financial expectations that are applied uniformly to all locations and regions in the US. Average work week is 55-60 hours per week which is fine but you always expected to work form home or on your days off. External marketing is expected to happen largely at the store level without more labor dollars offered to cover your absence in the store.
Advice to Management_y: Get back in touch with what it means to run a restaurant from an operations point of view for the last 5 years with the huge economic downturn our country has been facing and then ask for my help to turn it around. Its not the same as when you were operators.

Pros_y: Great brand, awesome name recognition. Fantastic product albeit a liitle over-priced for the ambiance. They like to compare themselves to other chain restaurants like Cheesecake Factory and PF Changs but their facitlities lack the correct ambiance for its price point.
Cons_y: Unrealistic financial expectations that are applied uniformly to all locations and regions in the US. Average work week is 55-60 hours per week which is fine but you always expected to work form home or on your days off. External marketing is expected to happen largely at the store level without more labor dollars offered to cover your absence in the store.
Advice to Management_y: Get back in touch with what it means to run a restaurant from an operations point of view for the last 5 years with the huge economic downturn our country has been facing and then ask for my help to turn it around. Its not the same as when you were operators.

Pros_x: Better than making minimum wage
Cons_x: Management plays favorites, super unprofessional, will change someone's schedule so they miss a shift and then fire them, writes people up for small things like not filling a salt shaker. No appreciation for work done. We had the worst numbers in our region, I believe due to management issues.
Advice to Management_x: Grow up... this isn't high school. There was one good manager that listened to employee's issues, and the kitchen manager was professional. But most of the management was outwardly rude to employees that they didn't like and would find small reasons to let people go.

Pros_y: Great brand, awesome name recognition. Fantastic product albeit a liitle over-priced for the ambiance. They like to compare themselves to other chain restaurants like Cheesecake Factory and PF Changs but their facitlities lack the correct ambiance for its price point.
Cons_y: Unrealistic financial expectations that are applied uniformly to all locations and regions in the US. Average work week is 55-60 hours per week which is fine but you always expected to work form home or on your days off. External marketing is expected to happen largely at the store level without more labor dollars offered to cover your absence in the store.
Advice to Management_y: Get back in touch with what it means to run a restaurant from an operations point of view for the last 5 years with the huge economic downturn our country has been facing and then ask for my help to turn it around. Its not the same as when you were operators.

Title_x: "Same social dynamic as a middle school; if you weren't part of the right clique you were doomed to fail."
Pros_x: The money is fantastic. Paid very low hourly, but you get to keep nearly all of your tips (just pay some out to the cooks and the hostess).
Cons_x: You are expected to pay for everything you need. The uniforms are very specific and you are not given an allowance or anything. You have to buy all your own shirts, pants, shoes, etc. The dissonance between management and servers is also far too much.
Advice to Management_x: I see a job as something professional. I did not share personal information unless asked specifically (so a non-answer would be awkward), yet I was reprimanded for how I felt about kids. in any other situation or with other people it would be a non-issue. But managers have far too much leeway and if they have a personal opinion about you that is negative, it affects how they treat you. My advice? train your managers to be more professional.

Title_x: "Same social dynamic as a middle school; if you weren't part of the right clique you were doomed to fail."
Pros_x: The money is fantastic. Paid very low hourly, but you get to keep nearly all of your tips (just pay some out to the cooks and the hostess).
Cons_x: You are expected to pay for everything you need. The uniforms are very specific and you are not given an allowance or anything. You have to buy all your own shirts, pants, shoes, etc. The dissonance between management and servers is also far too much.
Advice to Management_x: I see a job as something professional. I did not share personal information unless asked specifically (so a non-answer would be awkward), yet I was reprimanded for how I felt about kids. in any other situation or with other people it would be a non-issue. But managers have far too much leeway and if they have a personal opinion about you that is negative, it affects how they treat you. My advice? train your managers to be more professional.

Title_x: "Great co-workers, fun, relaxed environment. Good Management"
Pros_x: California Pizza kitchen is a great place for young people just starting out in the work force. It has a relaxed environment, the majority of my co-workers are fun, good people, and the restaurant's name is well established.
Cons_x: Sometimes company decisions regarding the addition or removal of certain food items just don't make any sense. Good items have been removed to be replaced by bad ones too often.
Advice to Management_x: Take more time to observe the work of your employees and their relationships with the guest clientele. I have seen way too many of my excellent co-workers get fired because of a small stupid mistake. I have also seen far too many awful co-workers able hang onto their job for way too long.

Title_x: "An O.K. place to work, but the concern for employees is in a downward spiral."
Pros_x: My coworkers are wonderful people. The financial return is good for the number of hours worked, but the work is definitely hard.
Cons_x: California Pizza Kitchen was bought about by Golden Gate Capital. Since that transition they have been cutting hours to spend less on labor as well as slashing the benefits offered to hourly employees such as paid vacation hours and free meals.
Advice to Management_x: Slashing hours and benefits reduced employee moral. As an employee of nearly six years, the only benefit I receive is $3 meals. The work is grueling and at my 5 year anniversary all I received was a card. I have begun to resent the company for bleeding us dry.
Pros_y: Great brand, awesome name recognition. Fantastic product albeit a liitle over-priced for the ambiance. They like to compare themselves to other chain restaurants like Cheesecake Factory and PF Changs but their facitlities lack the correct ambiance for its price point.
Cons_y: Unrealistic financial expectations that are applied uniformly to all locations and regions in the US. Average work week is 55-60 hours per week which is fine but you always expected to work form home or on your days off. External marketing is expected to happen largely at the store level without more labor dollars offered to cover your absence in the store.
Advice to Management_y: Get back in touch with what it means to run a restaurant from an operations point of view for the last 5 years with the huge economic downturn our country has been facing and then ask for my help to turn it around. Its not the same as when you were operators.

Pros_y: Great brand, awesome name recognition. Fantastic product albeit a liitle over-priced for the ambiance. They like to compare themselves to other chain restaurants like Cheesecake Factory and PF Changs but their facitlities lack the correct ambiance for its price point.
Cons_y: Unrealistic financial expectations that are applied uniformly to all locations and regions in the US. Average work week is 55-60 hours per week which is fine but you always expected to work form home or on your days off. External marketing is expected to happen largely at the store level without more labor dollars offered to cover your absence in the store.
Advice to Management_y: Get back in touch with what it means to run a restaurant from an operations point of view for the last 5 years with the huge economic downturn our country has been facing and then ask for my help to turn it around. Its not the same as when you were operators.

Title_x: "Good place to work, but not great."
Pros_x: Fun environment in which to work. Good people (mostly) on staff
Cons_x: Some racial issues within staff. Quick to cut hours
Advice to Management_x: Make employees feel more valued- preaching it is one thing, implementing it on a daily basis is another. The new contests and recently implemented tools for valuing the employees are much better, but there needs to be follow through in every aspect. The hours that are given need to be fair and not so preferential. It becomes problematic.
Pros_y: Great brand, awesome name recognition. Fantastic product albeit a liitle over-priced for the ambiance. They like to compare themselves to other chain restaurants like Cheesecake Factory and PF Changs but their facitlities lack the correct ambiance for its price point.
Cons_y: Unrealistic financial expectations that are applied uniformly to all locations and regions in the US. External marketing is expected to happen largely at the store level without more labor dollars offered to cover your absence in the store.
Advice to Management_y: Get back in touch with what it means to run a restaurant from an operations point of view for the last 5 years with the huge economic downturn our country has been facing and then ask for my help to turn it around. Its not the same as when you were operators.

Title_x: "New owners are a private equity firm and the greed shows"
Pros_x: A mid-cost dining experience that was affordable and family friendly, yet still busy and priced well enough that servers could still do well.
Cons_x: New owners are the private equity firm Golden Gate Capital, started by former employees from Bain Capital (Mitt Romney's company) and it shows. In the past few months, emphasis on service has degenerated to an emphasis on hard sales. New server reviews are formulated by PPA's or per person average. This isn't calculated by the amount of sales divided by the amount of guests. It is calculated as a point system that punishes the server if your items have low points. For example, if you have a family with two kids meals, those kids meals are worth less than one adult plain cheese pizza. Server sections are designated based on their PPA's as well as scheduling.. . We used to be allowed shift meals if we were scheduled to work a double shift (am and pm shift combined) but now we are not. On top of that, we aren't allowed to order food while on the clock nor allowed to take our leftovers home if we do order a meal. If we want to take anything home, we have to pay full cost. This is problematic from an affordability stand point but also that if you are working 11am to 10pm, you can't order food until you're off the clock. However, you also can't order food too late before closing time either. So you have to hope you're tables are finished, your side work is done, and you're off the clock at least an hour before closing time. If you are lucky enough to order food, you can't box the leftovers, but are required to throw the food away. We also have an increasingly limited selection of what we are allowed to order off the menu.. . Labor hours are calculated based on a complicated formula that is inconsistent with the realities of a day. For example, say there is constant growth in sales from 12pm until 2pm because of the lunch rush. However, sales and labor hours are monitored and the upper management will reprimand managers because there are still staff on the clock after 2:30. It doesn't take into account that we're not herding guests out the door, to allow the server to get off the clock. There should be more time allotted, more flexibility.. . Lastly, this week we found out that hourly employees, not sure if that includes back of the house, but bussers, hosts, and bartenders are having their wages reduced to minimum wage. This is regardless of their tenure or pay. For example, staff members who received $10 an hour or have been with the company for 15 years are as of immediately, receiving reduced wages to $7.25 an hour. It was an extreme shock.. . On top of all this, staff are being berated if they have too many work hours. I don't mean overtime, I mean that if they work 20 hours a week, and other employees release their shifts to be picked up, and another employee picks up those shifts, increasing their work hours to 30 or more, they get hassled. This is because if they maintain 25 hours or more a week, they qualify for insurance and an annual "bonus" of about $150 (depending on tenure). If they average less than 25 (for lower bonus or insurance qualifications) or 30 hours, they are disqualified or lose their eligibility.. . Changes to the menu, serving portions, cups, cutlery, plates, napkins, etc, have all been replaced with cheaper, smaller items, to allow for less portioning out and reduced costs and most importantly: increased profit. I have had many guest complaints because as they said, things "now feel cheapened".. . The company is being squeezed dry for profit at every turn and what was once a great company to work for, with great guests, is now feeling morally depleted and a lack of morale shows.
Advice to Management_x: To store managers, I feel sorry for you because i know how much you are being pressured literally hourly, with requests for updates, reports, action plans, and overall corrective measures to increase profit.. . To the upper management: you are killing the company. We have many guests who come in multiple times a week, not for special occassions but because they felt it was a welcoming, special place. Now they feel herded and unappreciated. We, the staff feel the same way.
Pros_y: Great brand, awesome name recognition. Fantastic product albeit a liitle over-priced for the ambiance. They like to compare themselves to other chain restaurants like Cheesecake Factory and PF Changs but their facitlities lack the correct ambiance for its price point.
Cons_y: Unrealistic financial expectations that are applied uniformly to all locations and regions in the US. Average work week is 55-60 hours per week which is fine but you always expected to work form home or on your days off. Title_x: "CPK is a good place for a part-time gig"
Pros_x: My particular store's management team is amazing and will work hard for their subordinates (i.e. help bus, run food, help with scheduling, help with anything they can really). . Work well with student schedule. . Amazing people to work with for the most part. . 50% food discount once a day (75% would be better...)
Cons_x: Late nights. . 4 table sections. . WAY, WAY, WAYYYY too much paper/plastic/glass waste! (Reduce & Recycle!!!). . Company is becoming increasingly difficult to deal with (upper management expects store managers to micromanage & managers have WAY too much to deal with). . In Utah, you only make $2.13 per hour + tips and tip out about 4% when everything is said and done. . Nit picky about uniform/hair standards (however, the company is loosening restrictions). . Breaks are often chaotic/rushed. . Bank-owned :(. . You have to charge people $1 for just about every little thing, which people get annoyed about and lessen your tip due to the charge/their annoyance
Advice to Management_x: I find it incredible that a manager could get in trouble (fired!) for allowing a server to have more than a 4 table section. However, I have heard good things about GJ & that the company's new direction should make the company blow up/be amazing.

Work well with student schedule. . Amazing people to work with for the most part. . 50% food discount once a day (75% would be better...)
Cons_x: Late nights. . 4 table sections. . WAY, WAY, WAYYYY too much paper/plastic/glass waste! (Reduce & Recycle!!!). . Company is becoming increasingly difficult to deal with (upper management expects store managers to micromanage & managers have WAY too much to deal with). . In Utah, you only make $2.13 per hour + tips and tip out about 4% when everything is said and done. . Nit picky about uniform/hair standards (however, the company is loosening restrictions). . Breaks are often chaotic/rushed. . Bank-owned :(. . You have to charge people $1 for just about every little thing, which people get annoyed about and lessen your tip due to the charge/their annoyance
Advice to Management_x: I find it incredible that a manager could get in trouble (fired!) for allowing a server to have more than a 4 table section. However, I have heard good things about GJ & that the company's new direction should make the company blow up/be amazing.
Pros_y: Great brand, awesome name recognition. Fantastic product albeit a liitle over-priced for the ambiance. They like to compare themselves to other chain restaurants like Cheesecake Factory and PF Changs but their facitlities lack the correct ambiance for its price point.
Cons_y: Unrealistic financial expectations that are applied uniformly to all locations and regions in the US. Average work week is 55-60 hours per week which is fine but you always expected to work form home or on your days off. External marketing is expected to happen largely at the store level without more labor dollars offered to cover your absence in the store.
Advice to Management_y: Get back in touch with what it means to run a restaurant from an operations point of view for the last 5 years with the huge economic downturn our country has been facing and then ask for my help to turn it around. Its not the same as when you were operators.

Cons_x: The company has made it impossible for employees at slower stores to financially survive due to blanket rules on how many tables a person can take. They treat slow stores and busy stores with the same rules. A small town CPK can't function like a Vegas CPK.
Pros_y: Great brand, awesome name recognition. Fantastic product albeit a liitle over-priced for the ambiance. They like to compare themselves to other chain restaurants like Cheesecake Factory and PF Changs but their facitlities lack the correct ambiance for its price point.
Cons_y: Unrealistic financial expectations that are applied uniformly to all locations and regions in the US. Average work week is 55-60 hours per week which is fine but you always expected to work form home or on your days off. External marketing is expected to happen largely at the store level without more labor dollars offered to cover your absence in the store.

Average work week is 55-60 hours per week which is fine but you always expected to work form home or on your days off. External marketing is expected to happen largely at the store level without more labor dollars offered to cover your absence in the store.
Advice to Management_y: Get back in touch with what it means to run a restaurant from an operations point of view for the last 5 years with the huge economic downturn our country has been facing and then ask for my help to turn it around. Its not the same as when you were operators.

Pros_x: CPK is on top of all the current tech out there to make the admin load on managers as easy as possible. Great food that is easy to keep consistent.
Cons_x: however being owned by essentially a hedge fund means that the ONLY thing that is important is the bottom line. So if you care about employee moral, customer service, or trying to grow top line sales this is not the place for you. (look at what they did to Macaroni Grill, bought for 88mil, sold for 55mil due to that philosophy)
Advice to Management_x: stop focusing on cutting every cost no matter the result.

Title_x: "A great place to work, especially when working around school."
Pros_x: - For the most part, the managers here are the greatest I have worked with in the restaurant industry.. - Their ability to work around your schedule is great.. - Constant incentives for high quality work.
Cons_x: - The hourly pay rate in Raleigh is way too low. The only money a server actually makes is from the TIP.. - Not having a consistent schedule can become a hassle.. - The best shifts are on the weekend, so working every weekend gets tiring.
Advice to Management_x: The quality of this company depends upon your leadership.
Pros_y: CPK is on top of all the current tech out there to make the admin load on managers as easy as possible. Great food that is easy to keep consistent.

Advice to Management_x: The quality of this company depends upon your leadership.
Pros_y: CPK is on top of all the current tech out there to make the admin load on managers as easy as possible. Great food that is easy to keep consistent.
Cons_y: however being owned by essentially a hedge fund means that the ONLY thing that is important is the bottom line. So if you care about employee moral, customer service, or trying to grow top line sales this is not the place for you. (look at what they did to Macaroni Grill, bought for 88mil, sold for 55mil due to that philosophy)
Advice to Management_y: stop focusing on cutting every cost no matter the result.

Pros_x: Working at the RSC does not feel like work. Things are changing but they are changing for the better.
Cons_x: I wish I didn't have a long commute but working with the people I work with I don't mind.
Advice to Management_x: Take care of your people and they will take care of you.

Title_x: "A great place to work--challenging, rewarding, autonomy, family-oriented!"
Pros_x: This company believes in it's people. Thrives on two-way communication and the "people in charge" are seen as "partners" not "bosses".. . Fun is encouraged at work. Not just to goof off but in a fun, productive and meaningful way that promotes a sense of team work and family.. . Direct communication with CEO. He isn't someone who hides in an "ivory tower". He believes in really knowing everyone in every position. He walks the talk.
Cons_x: The speed in which we change. It's not really a con but I wish we were better equipped at communicating change at all levels. I think that occurs no matter where you are :).
Pros_y: CPK is on top of all the current tech out there to make the admin load on managers as easy as possible. Great food that is easy to keep consistent.
Cons_y: however being owned by essentially a hedge fund means that the ONLY thing that is important is the bottom line. So if you care about employee moral, customer service, or trying to grow top line sales this is not the place for you. (look at what they did to Macaroni Grill, bought for 88mil, sold for 55mil due to that philosophy)
Advice to Management_y: stop focusing on cutting every cost no matter the result.

Pros_x: I have worked in both the restaurants and at the Restaurant Support Center, and I can't say enough good things about CPK. It was like a family in the restaurants; the hours were great for being in school, and the training was intense to set you up for success. At the RSC, the culture is no less awesome. The CEO (GJ Hart) has made some amazing changes to the company in the last 2 years. Before he joined our team, it was still a great place to work, but things had become comfortable and we weren't pushing the envelope as a forward thinking company like we used to. That has totally turned around; we are changing our look in the restaurants and even hand tossing all of our pizza dough now! We are still a corporation and sales are our main focus right now (as with any business), but CPK appreciates its employees in good times and in bad. GJ is a great leader and we're definitely going places!
Cons_x: I really don't have anything bad to say about CPK. We are going through changes to make us better, and with any change there are some struggles. However, I believe in the company and have embraced the changes because they are for the good of the company. I was promoted from within and given the opportunity to prove and make a career for myself because upper management believed in me. I would call myself a success story!
Pros_y: CPK is on top of all the current tech out there to make the admin load on managers as easy as possible. Great food that is easy to keep consistent.
Cons_y: however being owned by essentially a hedge fund means that the ONLY thing that is important is the bottom line. So if you care about employee moral, customer service, or trying to grow top line sales this is not the place for you. Cons_x: I really don't have anything bad to say about CPK. We are going through changes to make us better, and with any change there are some struggles. However, I believe in the company and have embraced the changes because they are for the good of the company. I was promoted from within and given the opportunity to prove and make a career for myself because upper management believed in me. I would call myself a success story!
Pros_y: CPK is on top of all the current tech out there to make the admin load on managers as easy as possible. Great food that is easy to keep consistent.
Cons_y: however being owned by essentially a hedge fund means that the ONLY thing that is important is the bottom line. So if you care about employee moral, customer service, or trying to grow top line sales this is not the place for you. (look at what they did to Macaroni Grill, bought for 88mil, sold for 55mil due to that philosophy)
Advice to Management_y: stop focusing on cutting every cost no matter the result.

Pros_x: I have worked in both the restaurants and at the Restaurant Support Center, and I can't say enough good things about CPK. It was like a family in the restaurants; the hours were great for being in school, and the training was intense to set you up for success. At the RSC, the culture is no less awesome. The CEO (GJ Hart) has made some amazing changes to the company in the last 2 years. Before he joined our team, it was still a great place to work, but things had become comfortable and we weren't pushing the envelope as a forward thinking company like we used to. That has totally turned around; we are changing our look in the restaurants and even hand tossing all of our pizza dough now! We are still a corporation and sales are our main focus right now (as with any business), but CPK appreciates its employees in good times and in bad. GJ is a great leader and we're definitely going places!
Cons_x: I really don't have anything bad to say about CPK. We are going through changes to make us better, and with any change there are some struggles. However, I believe in the company and have embraced the changes because they are for the good of the company. I was promoted from within and given the opportunity to prove and make a career for myself because upper management believed in me. I would call myself a success story!

Title_x: "Massachusetts Experience: If I could give the company 0 stars, I would."
Pros_x: 1.) Better than working retail (but that is almost any job in my opinion).. 2.) Your co-workers (that is, only the people on the exact same level as you) generally are friendly and help you when you ask.. 3.) The company somewhat tries to establish a culture about working there.. 4.) When I worked there, the dress code was pretty easy and fair. I heard it's gotten much more picky at the expense of the employees since I left though.
Cons_x: Disclaimer: What I am about to share are a number of reasons why I personally feel this company is a bad employer. Not everyone will have the same experiences as me, but you should be aware of what I experienced. This is not meant as a rant.. . 1.) Your pay is awful, even though they claim it's "competitive." In fact, I had my pay slashed by dollars per hour while working there. They felt that, as a tipped employee, I no longer needed my fixed hourly wage (the state minimum wage), and that my tips plus a menial wage of $4-6/hour would cover the difference. You could get paid WAY better somewhere else, don’t let them stop you from looking as I did MANY times.. . 2.) You will sign both an at-will employment agreement and an arbitration agreement - multiple times. I had to sign many legal papers twice while employed there, and there were at least 10-15 pages of legalese between all of the forms I signed (there were others in addition to the aforementioned two). Essentially, this company feels that it's acceptable to fire you whenever they want, and for whatever reason (or no reason) they want. Also, forget about a trial by jury when your life goes bottoms up because you've lost your job for no reason, because you either waive that right or don't keep your job at CPK. Do YOU want that kind of job security?. . 3.) No sick days, no vacation days. Unless you're in management, don't think about getting a paid sick or vacation day. Ever. I never was offered one, nor was anyone I know that wasn't a manager of some sort unless you count company contests that they conducted. The people who won those were probably the only non-management that got vacation days, and to my recollection none of them worked with me.. . 4.) Favoritism. You'll hear this complaint a lot with many businesses, but my managers played favorites over the most immature stuff. Yes, the managers do try to form relationships with underlings outside of work (see below), which is EXTREMELY unprofessional and explains why the favoritism exists. I have seen multiple times managers keep servers in the WORST sections of the restaurant over and over, while other managers put some servers in the BEST sections of the restaurant every single time. There was at least one server who quit because they would always get the same awful section every day (maybe they got lucky if the manager who made the floor plan thought they were hot), and I can tell you that it was one of the hardest sections to sit. Also, expect to get disciplined while others don’t despite doing the same thing. That happened CONSTANTLY.. . 5.) Unprofessional staff rampant. Managers sleep with servers, servers sleep with servers, people seek blatantly unprofessional relationships and make sure to bring it up in front of guests. This has been just SOME of my experience, but I feel that it was a pretty big problem that the general manager (GM) and assistant general manager (AGM) either weren't competent enough to pick up on the relationships (they also both had outside relationships with certain individuals in question) or just blatantly disregarded their existence, not sure what happened there.. . 6.) Advancement doesn't exist. They say they promote from within. Don't believe it if you hear it, unless you define promotion as going from being a host to being a server. If you wan't professional advancement, look for a job with the corporate office or their call center, but I wouldn’t expect much if any professional advancement without a degree, pure dumb luck, or both.. . 7.) Scheduling is awful. I wish I could take a picture of my HotSchedules (scheduling app) app on my iPhone as proof. They literally block you from taking anything that MIGHT be a busy day months in advance. No joke. They blocked Black Friday in 2013 almost a year before (I still had access then). Then they blocked Valentine’s Day, Mother’s Day, Patriot’s Day, and any major or minor holiday from being asked for off MONTHS in advance. That also includes any vacation days the local schools might be having because little kids might come in with their families (it's a family restaurant). My scheduling manager made asking for days off extremely stressful. If you are a student, I HIGHLY advise you not work for this company.
Advice to Management_x: Stop caring about the bottom line and start caring about the hosts, take-out servers, counter servers and general servers that are the reason you actually make money. If they all walked out tomorrow and there were no replacements, you'd be getting ready for chapter 11 pretty soon after.

Cons_y: however being owned by essentially a hedge fund means that the ONLY thing that is important is the bottom line. So if you care about employee moral, customer service, or trying to grow top line sales this is not the place for you. Title_x: "My experience might have been atypical from others"
Pros_x: Lots of people go, so servers make a lot of money.
Cons_x: -Management and corporate depend too much on statistics concerning their server's ability to sell specific items (like dessert, a beer, a specific type of wine, etc), which made for a stressful work environment.. -When I worked there the restaurant was brand new and servers often had to deal with a slow kitchen because back of the house workers were constantly quitting.
Advice to Management_x: Keeping your workers happy = successful restaurant.

Pros_x: Discounted meals when you work. I think they take a few dollars out of your paycheck for every meal you order. If you come in when you're not working, you get 20% off of your entire check at any location. Discounted gym membership to 24 hour fitness. Easy sidework during the day shift.
Cons_x: You are required to pay for your work shirts issued by the company. Requesting time off can be hard.
Advice to Management_x: Show more appreciation for employees who do well, rather than just highlighting mistakes. Don't be so pushy with your "soft selling" techniques.

Cons_y: however being owned by essentially a hedge fund means that the ONLY thing that is important is the bottom line. So if you care about employee moral, customer service, or trying to grow top line sales this is not the place for you. (look at what they did to Macaroni Grill, bought for 88mil, sold for 55mil due to that philosophy)
Advice to Management_y: stop focusing on cutting every cost no matter the result.

Title_x: "A great company to work for prior to the transfer to new ownership. Now, nuetral. Potential still there"
Pros_x: great company in terms of promoting from within. Good company to grow with. Opportunities are available if you work towards them.
Cons_x: the company has changed ownership and the new team seems to be more concerned with the companies success than their employees success and happiness. They seem to have reduced us all to unimportant, expendable numbers. The original company belief that happy employees make better employees seems to have left with the original owners.
Advice to Management_x: treat your team members as important and valuable, respect their feelings and opinions. Listen

Cons_x: Corporate job with too many regional managers
Advice to Management_x: quit.
Pros_y: CPK is on top of all the current tech out there to make the admin load on managers as easy as possible. Great food that is easy to keep consistent.
Cons_y: however being owned by essentially a hedge fund means that the ONLY thing that is important is the bottom line. So if you care about employee moral, customer service, or trying to grow top line sales this is not the place for you. (look at what they did to Macaroni Grill, bought for 88mil, sold for 55mil due to that philosophy)
Advice to Management_y: stop focusing on cutting every cost no matter the result.

Pros_x: Strong leadership, opportunities to grow, a culture where you can be who you are and where you're allowed to being ideas to the table and have them heard. In addition to this, we are encouraged and allowed to have fun at work whether it be through social office gatherings or in our departments. Community service is also strongly encouraged and supported which is really important to me.
Cons_x: No cons. I honestly enjoy working at the Restaurant Support Center. It's a fun, diverse and welcoming environment.

Pros_x: The employees are non replaceable.
Cons_x: Since company was bought it is all about the bottom line. They are getting rid of great long time, loyal management with many years at the company. Employees are no longer cared about nor does new senior management even try to build a relationship or get to know anybody. Very sad
Advice to Management_x: Flip the company, move on so the few remaining loyal employees don't loose their jobs too.

Title_x: "good place to work, great co-workers. corporate needs help."
Pros_x: the people i work with are amazing and extremely fun. a very diverse group of people who know how to have fun at work while pleasing guests.
Cons_x: upper management doesn't know what they're doing. constant menu changes, many employee benefits have been taken away. the upper-management seems to constantly change and just seems very unstable. also, we cater to very large parties and in the near future all restaurants are doing away with gratuity, so when that $300.00+ or $400.00+ bill comes, you better hope they know tipping procedures.
Advice to Management_x: be consistent, know you customer and give them what they want, not what you think they'll like, and stop taking away great things from the menu only to replace them with items that are likely going to be done away with!

Cons_y: Since company was bought it is all about the bottom line. They are getting rid of great long time, loyal management with many years at the company. Employees are no longer cared about nor does new senior management even try to build a relationship or get to know anybody. Very sad
Advice to Management_y: Flip the company, move on so the few remaining loyal employees don't loose their jobs too.

Cons_x: Very corporate, no room for growth

Pros_x: Great benefits. Great opportunity for a manager to learn how to balance FOH & BOH duties. Wonderful standards for cleanliness and food freshness.
Cons_x: Lack of focus. Cutbacks in quality for guest service. Admittedly, my local regional manager was a great example of the Peter Principle.
Advice to Management_x: Push managers in their strong areas while making their weak areas the bridge to advancement and not the reason they dread coming to work.

Title_x: "GJ Hart has no heart and along with his Texas Roadhouse team he's ruined a great company!"
Pros_x: Gj throws million dollar conferences, he knows how to party.
Cons_x: GJ doesn't do what he says he's going to do. He told us trust is earned as he recruited from Texas Roadhouse to replace many of us that helped build the the company. Some needed to go but many were fired with no documentation. The Regional Partner from 2012 was awarded that title in March 2013 and fired in October 2013. He granted options to Regional Partners claiming he was sharing in the upside. As people were let go they were told by Brad Gramlich that the options they owned belonged to them. That when there was a qualifying event they would be evaluated and paid out. Well...the options were evaluated and paid out at $0. CPK made $70,000,000 in EBITDAR and GJ makes over $2,000,000 a year and my options are worth $0 a share....so much for the past 20 years. We have an operators conference at the Ritz Carlton that costs over $1,000,000. We have rolled back wages for FOH and soon BOH employees. We have squeezed labor and reduced manager bonuses. The company has lost its diversity and now is turning into a good old boys club.
Advice to Management_x: Be honest, do what you say you're going to do. Remember trust is earned. It's very disappointing this company use to care about the people and now it's all about GJ's pockets and sharing the upside with your Texas Roadhouse boys. Brad Gramlich should not be running "the people department". Kim Boerema is the worst COO.
Pros_y: Great benefits. Great opportunity for a manager to learn how to balance FOH & BOH duties. Wonderful standards for cleanliness and food freshness.
Cons_y: Lack of focus. Cutbacks in quality for guest service. Admittedly, my local regional manager was a great example of the Peter Principle.

Title_x: "Great work atmosphere! I have worked at CPK for 5 years."
Pros_x: The opportunities for social interaction, networking with regular customers, moderate income, freedom in creating your own style of working as well as flexible hours.
Cons_x: Rude customers, high stress work environment at times, mismanagement by corporate level in recent years.
Advice to Management_x: GJ is doing a good job so far, the need to focus on repeat customers is a necessity.

Title_x: "Started out great, declined over the last year with new CEO who just doesn't get it."
Pros_x: fun co workers,location was convenient. Customers were pleasant.
Cons_x: constantly changing schedule, no respect for employees, constantly changing menu (customers don't like that), not enough hours. When I first started the company cared about its employees and treated them like partners in the customer service model. Over the last year with the new CEO really taking over the company has made changes and not for the better. All the perks of working for this company are gone. Long time employees who have loved CPK for a long time are no longer happy and submitting resumes to change jobs. That speaks volumes for the environment. Nobody would change jobs after 10-15 plus years unless its just a necessity. But that is happening. Unhappy employees and management does not care. General Manager will tell you that his concern if for his restaurant and customers. While I do understand what he is trying to say, his manner of conveying information comes across like he does not care about his employees. Its a partnership and CPK would do well to remember that happy employees, equals happy customers, equals happy management and a happy bottom line. Its a balancing act and this company has lost its balance
Advice to Management_x: Take a look at your business model and realize that employees, customers and businesses all form a partnership and must work harmoniously. Perhaps ask employees what they think and realize you have human being working for you. Stop treating them so badly. The economy forces them to stay but if there were more jobs the employees would have left by now.

Pros_x: Fun, talented, and organized staff. Had the Opportunity to work for California Pizza Kitchen around the Boston area. All of the California Pizza Restaurants that i have worked at had a very good staff. Managers are very knowledgeable and most will do what they can for you.
Cons_x: Chain restaurant that does not offer a variety of food. I feel like some major Restaurants like the one located at the Prudential center should have the ability to tailor the menu's to suit each city. Customer ask's what's your soup of the day? Server's only response is we only have two soups that haven't changed in the past 2+ years that come pre made in plastic bags, gross…
Advice to Management_x: Let your manager's have less restraints on tailoring the menu!

Pros_x: The money can be great especially when you have seniority. There are opportunities to grow within the company so it is a great career path for a driven person without an education.
Cons_x: CPK has changed the work environment greatly. 8 years ago I was so impressed and then ownership changed. The employee satisfaction is no longer a concern. They have cut benefits and pay and let the employees know they are disposable. Cleanliness is no longer a concern because they don't even want to pay employees long enough to clean. They are so concerned with making every penny they can they are losing respect of their own employees and their patrons!
Advice to Management_x: Remember where this company started. It had a solid reputation and good customer feedback. Stop ruining a good thing!

Pros_x: The managers are nice, and everyone who worked there was pleasant. Their training system is tried and true.
Cons_x: Their training system is a huge problem. It is only made for people who can read - and only read - in order to learn. There is no video substitution or anything, and they expect you to learn 75% of the menu in a week. They will tell you that's not the case, but don't listen - it's exactly the case.
Advice to Management_x: Realize that there is more than one to learn. For instance, some people are visual, some learn by doing, and others learn by listening. Make it accessible to all, not just the select few who can adapt to *your* way of learning.

Title_x: "Used to be great. Now its all about money and nothing is good enough."
Pros_x: Management pays well, but its still not worth it.
Cons_x: All the new management is about the bottom line and doesn't care about any of the people. They lie to your face while they take away all of your benefits. Several managers worked over a year without a single vacation (RP never approved).
Advice to Management_x: Get out before its too late. They will sell the company. That is what Golden Gate Capital does. Its all about making money for shareholders. Has nothing to do with food quality, hospitality, or cleanliness anymore.

Pros_x: Work-life balance was wonderful - company was flexible. However, there were times when others took advantage of the flexibility and abused taking time off. Management would not address certain individuals causing misgivings about how some were treated vs. others who did not take nearly as much advantage in a similar situation. Overall work-life was good.
Cons_x: There was a lot of favoritism - if you brown nosed enough to certain people, you were in. There were some raging alcoholics, harassers who were promoted and praised. Prior to new management, co-founders were volatile and unpredictable and did not value loyalty. They and other upper management would portray that they valued employees, but they were clearly in it for themselves.
Advice to Management_x: I can't speak about current management, because shortly after acquiring CPK the layoffs began.

Pros_x: Never a slow day. You will always keep busy and the time does fly by.
Cons_x: They have come a long way from where they were. Successful company for many years and now they have changed EVERYTHING to try and get this back.
Advice to Management_x: Keep things fresh and simple. Don't open up to too many options, tools, charts, etc.

Pros_x: The managers are given a dining out card to use on their friends and family. The only thing that you are unable to purchase is alcoholic beverages.
Cons_x: Work life balance is preached but not practiced, while in training there is only 10 hours a day for the trainee to work. I found myself consistently working 12-13 hours and when I would get ready to leave upper management would say "leaving already?"
Advice to Management_x: Practice what you preach and when a trainee asks questions help them out don't say you don't know or tell them to go read the book!

Cons_y: Work life balance is preached but not practiced, while in training there is only 10 hours a day for the trainee to work. I found myself consistently working 12-13 hours and when I would get ready to leave upper management would say "leaving already?"
Advice to Management_y: Practice what you preach and when a trainee asks questions help them out don't say you don't know or tell them to go read the book!

Pros_x: You can make decent money serving. Usually, at least with my store, it is a relaxed dining atmosphere where employees can relax at their job.

Pros_x: The food is good and they have gone back to encouraging individuality.
Cons_x: Managers don't appreciate the GOOD staff they have. They'll push five excellent employees out the door, just to get ten mediocre employees on the clock. I've been there for three years, and I'm still treated like I just walked onto the floor yesterday. They take advantage of the good workers, and don't reprimand the ones doing wrong. And upper management keeps saying they support the employees, when they really don't care at all.
Advice to Management_x: Show a little employee love, and you'll get some back. When I started at CPK, they took care of us. Now we're all disposable.

Cons_y: Work life balance is preached but not practiced, while in training there is only 10 hours a day for the trainee to work. I found myself consistently working 12-13 hours and when I would get ready to leave upper management would say "leaving already?"
Advice to Management_y: Practice what you preach and when a trainee asks questions help them out don't say you don't know or tell them to go read the book!

Title_x: "Had great opportunities but the politics were hard to get past"
Pros_x: While under the original owners, I took advantage of the opportunities within the company and moved up were I could. From server to bartender to in store trainer to corporate trainer to DSL (Dining Shift Leader). The best part was being a corporate trainer or "Opening Team Trainer". Compensation was decent, perks of good health insurance and stipends while traveling were great. I made good money and while working full time with the company, bought a car, a house and went back to school.
Cons_x: The politics is what really gets you. I stopped moving up in the company and working as a DSL and Opening Team Trainer while the original owners were still in place. Too much sexual harassment, gossiping, backstabbing and the lack of education in many individuals made it a tough environment to succeed in. I did work under the new owners, but only as a server and bartender part time; therefore, I can't really comment on how things have been since the takeover.
Advice to Management_x: Listen to your employees, especially ones that have been there a long time and do a good job. They care about their work, the company and want to be successful so listen to their concerns, take their advice and ideas and show that you care about them.
Pros_y: Great pay..great culture in theory. Great operating systems. Diverse culture, opportunity for advancement
Cons_y: Favoritism ... Had gm sleeping with assistant manager. When I started to question , after 7 yrs employment I was asked to leave due to gm feeling uncomfortable???? Gj... I suggest you stop trying to reinvent and get back to basics
Advice to Management_y: Follow policy.. Don't look the other way when someone breaks rules just to be nice. If I was more vindictive I would have had a great law suit!!

Cons_y: Favoritism ... Had gm sleeping with assistant manager. When I started to question , after 7 yrs employment I was asked to leave due to gm feeling uncomfortable???? Gj... I suggest you stop trying to reinvent and get back to basics

Title_x: "Had great opportunities but the politics were hard to get past"
Pros_x: While under the original owners, I took advantage of the opportunities within the company and moved up were I could. From server to bartender to in store trainer to corporate trainer to DSL (Dining Shift Leader). The best part was being a corporate trainer or "Opening Team Trainer". Compensation was decent, perks of good health insurance and stipends while traveling were great. I made good money and while working full time with the company, bought a car, a house and went back to school.
Cons_x: The politics is what really gets you. I stopped moving up in the company and working as a DSL and Opening Team Trainer while the original owners were still in place. Too much sexual harassment, gossiping, backstabbing and the lack of education in many individuals made it a tough environment to succeed in. I did work under the new owners, but only as a server and bartender part time; therefore, I can't really comment on how things have been since the takeover.
Advice to Management_x: Listen to your employees, especially ones that have been there a long time and do a good job. They care about their work, the company and want to be successful so listen to their concerns, take their advice and ideas and show that you care about them.
Pros_y: Great pay..great culture in theory. Great operating systems. Diverse culture, opportunity for advancement
Cons_y: Favoritism ... Had gm sleeping with assistant manager. When I started to question , after 7 yrs employment I was asked to leave due to gm feeling uncomfortable???? Gj... I suggest you stop trying to reinvent and get back to basics
Advice to Management_y: Follow policy.. Don't look the other way when someone breaks rules just to be nice. If I was more vindictive I would have had a great law suit!!

Pros_x: Great coworkers, benefits were good
Cons_x: high demands, constant changes, menu updates multiple times a year
Pros_y: Great coworkers, benefits were good
Cons_y: high demands, constant changes, menu updates multiple times a year

Pros_x: At CPK, it was great to work alongside people that were just as friendly and awesome to be around - including your general managers and those above you. Everyone worked together to really reach the peak at where we wanted to be. The food is phenomenal, and as menus roll out, you get to taste the new items without buying them which gives you an opportunity to sell, sell, sell.
Cons_x: There's a relatively small staff. People don't really want to pick up your shifts, even though you are constantly picking up theirs when they need the assistance.
Advice to Management_x: I think it would be great to implement even more extensive training that would go into all of the positions in the restaurant, even if you are only going to be front of the house.
Pros_y: Great coworkers, benefits were good
Cons_y: high demands, constant changes, menu updates multiple times a year

Pros_x: In the past company spent outrageous amounts of money. They are working on bringing thier spending back in line with the rest of the industry. Long time employees hate it. Cons_x: They are making some mistakes along the way. But, they are quick to admit it and adjust. Still haven't figured out exactly what they want to be. Many long term managers have left; many, many new managers in the system.

Title_x: "Great company to work for in this industry!"
Pros_x: It is as laid back as a restaurant can be. The company wants you to be your unique self. I got a bonus for being there a year. Scheduling is flexible and easily accessed via the internet. Also, at my location the latest we stay open in 9:30!
Cons_x: The only complaint I have isn't something the company can control. It is an entry level job where a lot of first time employees start their working experience, therefore they just don't care about their job performance.
Advice to Management_x: Maybe give more evaluations of foh staff with a small bonus or raise as an incentive to do well. I'm talking as little as free movie tickets. A little goes a long way.
Pros_y: Great coworkers, benefits were good
Cons_y: high demands, constant changes, menu updates multiple times a year

Title_x: "what you see is what you get"
Pros_x: Staff front and back house are mostly fun to work with. upper management works hard and are knowledgeable. computer system is simple to learn. food is pretty good to good. drinks good. I'm a server and management works really hard to work with my availability
Cons_x: front of the house is constantly reminded to push loyalty cards, promotions and use a "kinda" script when approaching guests. we're also pushed to ask guests to fill out surveys online to raise our satisfaction ratings in the eyes of corporate.
Pros_y: Great coworkers, benefits were good
Cons_y: high demands, constant changes, menu updates multiple times a year

Title_x: "Horrible compensation by no fault of the company. The guest's who dined at the location I worked for barely tipped for their pre-packaged out of a bag food. (Understandably so.) Outdated system used to seat guest's (like Dark ages outdated), and extensive training on irrelevant information that was not actually relevant or helpful on the job."
Pros_x: It is a job. If you are unemployed it can offer you some sort of compensation.
Cons_x: Strange corporate culture. Not a team environment like they advertise. There was a click of employees with the most seniority, like in most restaurants, however it was just sad to watch because they valued such a horrible job so highly. They definitely have their employees drinking some kind of cool-aide.
Pros_y: Great coworkers, benefits were good
Cons_y: high demands, constant changes, menu updates multiple times a year

Pros_x: Competitive salary and benefit package
Cons_x: Company is owned by a private equity firm- not a restaurant group. Constant management turn over. Much of the original CPK is gone- new company has slowly laid off long term employees at the corporate level. Long hours. Sales based bonus system
Advice to Management_x: The term jack of all trades, master of none applies here. When you roll out several different initiatives all at the same time- it is counter-productive. Also- you have many long term back of house employees who are very over-paid and send labor percentages soaring. To compensate- you cut labor dollars from the front of house- then you wonder why your guests do not come back. You need to start listening to your managers and supporting them- constantly training new ones that don't last must be getting very expensive for you.

Cons_x: GJ Hart has proven to be a "one trick pony" who has taken a sucessful concept and culture and tried to turn it into another Texas Roadhouse. What an overrated, egotistical clown. After cleaning house he has brought in more and more people from Texas Roadhouse as if that will save his bacon.. Hopefully, Golden Gate will see the light and dump the mess he has created.
Advice to Management_x: Punt...
Pros_y: Competitive salary and benefit package
Cons_y: Company is owned by a private equity firm- not a restaurant group. Constant management turn over. Much of the original CPK is gone- new company has slowly laid off long term employees at the corporate level. Long hours. Sales based bonus system
Advice to Management_y: The term jack of all trades, master of none applies here. When you roll out several different initiatives all at the same time- it is counter-productive. Also- you have many long term back of house employees who are very over-paid and send labor percentages soaring. To compensate- you cut labor dollars from the front of house- then you wonder why your guests do not come back. You need to start listening to your managers and supporting them- constantly training new ones that don't last must be getting very expensive for you.

Pros_x: A great serving Job with out ever having to sing happy birthday to anyone. Management is pretty trusting, as a server only you know the real need of your patrons so management lets you make most of the important decisions when it comes to comping, birthdays, coupons, gratuities, etc.... all they do is provide the swipe minimum questions asked. best of all they try to maintain a laid back California Atmosphere. Did I mention you Don't sing happy birthdays here!!. sales contest are great and fun. and every once in a while you get cash prizes just for memorizing the company mission statement. so being bilingual is a plus. if you work hard you will be noticed, i went from Dishwasher to server in a few months, training is top notch.
Cons_x: Employees, try your best to not get involved romantically with other employees whether from BOH or FOH. The last thing you want to lose you job over is a scandal. also Do not ever come to work high. or jokingly reassure a customer that you did not spit in his food. Cause you will get fired!! Basically use you common sense.
Advice to Management_x: Managers Please stay out of the kitchen on Packed out nights. If it takes you 5 minutes to make a salad on a slow shift, nobody wants you making their salad, pasta, or pizza on a busy night, more likely that your services are needed out on the floor
Pros_y: Competitive salary and benefit package
Cons_y: Company is owned by a private equity firm- not a restaurant group. Constant management turn over. Much of the original CPK is gone- new company has slowly laid off long term employees at the corporate level. Long hours. Sales based bonus system

Management is pretty trusting, as a server only you know the real need of your patrons so management lets you make most of the important decisions when it comes to comping, birthdays, coupons, gratuities, etc.... all they do is provide the swipe minimum questions asked. best of all they try to maintain a laid back California Atmosphere. Did I mention you Don't sing happy birthdays here!!. sales contest are great and fun. and every once in a while you get cash prizes just for memorizing the company mission statement. so being bilingual is a plus. if you work hard you will be noticed, i went from Dishwasher to server in a few months, training is top notch.
Cons_x: Employees, try your best to not get involved romantically with other employees whether from BOH or FOH. The last thing you want to lose you job over is a scandal. also Do not ever come to work high. or jokingly reassure a customer that you did not spit in his food. Cause you will get fired!! Basically use you common sense.
Advice to Management_x: Managers Please stay out of the kitchen on Packed out nights. If it takes you 5 minutes to make a salad on a slow shift, nobody wants you making their salad, pasta, or pizza on a busy night, more likely that your services are needed out on the floor
Pros_y: Competitive salary and benefit package
Cons_y: Company is owned by a private equity firm- not a restaurant group. Constant management turn over. Much of the original CPK is gone- new company has slowly laid off long term employees at the corporate level. Long hours. Sales based bonus system
Advice to Management_y: The term jack of all trades, master of none applies here. When you roll out several different initiatives all at the same time- it is counter-productive. Also- you have many long term back of house employees who are very over-paid and send labor percentages soaring. To compensate- you cut labor dollars from the front of house- then you wonder why your guests do not come back. You need to start listening to your managers and supporting them- constantly training new ones that don't last must be getting very expensive for you.

Pros_x: Great training process. Managers make sure you know what you need to know before starting. Haven't had one bad managerial experience in a year of working. Employees are great as well.
Cons_x: The brand is trying to recover from a string of bad years so the expectations can seem a little high at times. Upper management pops in and out to check up on things and really puts pressure on the staff.

Cons_y: Company is owned by a private equity firm- not a restaurant group. Constant management turn over. Much of the original CPK is gone- new company has slowly laid off long term employees at the corporate level. Long hours. Sales based bonus system
Advice to Management_y: The term jack of all trades, master of none applies here. When you roll out several different initiatives all at the same time- it is counter-productive. Also- you have many long term back of house employees who are very over-paid and send labor percentages soaring. To compensate- you cut labor dollars from the front of house- then you wonder why your guests do not come back. You need to start listening to your managers and supporting them- constantly training new ones that don't last must be getting very expensive for you.

To compensate- you cut labor dollars from the front of house- then you wonder why your guests do not come back. You need to start listening to your managers and supporting them- constantly training new ones that don't last must be getting very expensive for you.

Title_x: "Use to be one of the most dynamic places to dine and wrk for but my, my, my how have times changed tor the worst. So sad"
Pros_x: Flexible hrs, great co-workers and decent local management. I started as a server while in grad school: money was great and the we had organic joy not corporate mandated -- think high five -- friendliness.
Cons_x: Since Golden Gate.. vacation hour program for non-salary ppl replaced. health insurance sucks p.s. stop blaming Obama for this change. employee benefits slashed -- we pay a great deal more for employee meals. employees treated not as valued teammates or partners, now they are throw away parts. T/o people are expected to work harder with less pay. New Regional directors suck -- very rude, self-important and ineffective.. work environment very stressful
Advice to Management_x: Where do I start? The new owners -- Golden Gate (think Romney and Bains corp.) have for the most part greatly damaged a formerly great brand in the name of making profits for the top brass. Cheaper ingredients, smaller portions and different recipes have decreased guest food satisfaction and return business. Corp. knows this but still blame FOH staff for failure to meet sales projection.. . Second, mid-management purge -- gms, rd's and regional veeps -- have led to new mid-managers who are clueless in understanding the CPK brand or culture. However, since they have titles the behave as arrogant know-it-alls. They are strongly lacking interpersonal skills, hence, their communication is extremely condescending.. . On the corp. level the are floundering big time. They try so many Johnny-come-lately and ineffective promotions that guest dread. A la Bains corp, they know how to ruthlessly reap profit but they are clueless in how to operate a restaurant. And on the corp level as well, they have a tin ear. They created a new narrative and despite facts-on-the-ground saying otherwise, they are rigidly sticking to what ain't working.. . Bottom line: You may have needed new innovations to keep the old CPK afloat but you medicine is making CPK sicker. Please sell to competent management team. And stop creating G J Hart cult of personalities mini me's
Pros_y: Competitive salary and benefit package
Cons_y: Company is owned by a private equity firm- not a restaurant group. Constant management turn over. Much of the original CPK is gone- new company has slowly laid off long term employees at the corporate level. Long hours. Sales based bonus system
Advice to Management_y: The term jack of all trades, master of none applies here. When you roll out several different initiatives all at the same time- it is counter-productive. Title_x: "Before the Golden Gate capital buy-out the company felt more about people, now it feels all about money."
Pros_x: Food is great and fresh. They have high standards for that. They have a good reputation.
Cons_x: Management lacks passion for the industry in WA. Senior Management is not interested in developing those committed to the company and continued to hire externally. Had a sense of discrimination within the company. Good work went unnoticed unless you pointed it out.
Advice to Management_x: Promote those who love the brand and committed to the company. You cant teach that! Passion and attitude is everything in this industry!

Pros_x: Plenty of opportunity to cross-train (server/bartender/host/take out). Lots of opportunity for promotion to manager from hourly employee, if you so desire.
Cons_x: Too much change at the leadership level leading to inconsistencies at the restaurant level. Benefits sliding downhill fast. Long-term employees had their pay and benefits cut, food that used to be deeply discounted for hourly employees is now 50% off, which is still quite expensive.
Advice to Management_x: Treat your hourly employees with dignity, as was done in the Rick-and-Larry-era, and the guests will return. People dine out for the experience as much as the food, and unhappy staff leads to unhappy guests.

Also- you have many long term back of house employees who are very over-paid and send labor percentages soaring. To compensate- you cut labor dollars from the front of house- then you wonder why your guests do not come back. You need to start listening to your managers and supporting them- constantly training new ones that don't last must be getting very expensive for you.

Pros_x: Plenty of opportunity to cross-train (server/bartender/host/take out). Lots of opportunity for promotion to manager from hourly employee, if you so desire.
Cons_x: Too much change at the leadership level leading to inconsistencies at the restaurant level. Benefits sliding downhill fast. Long-term employees had their pay and benefits cut, food that used to be deeply discounted for hourly employees is now 50% off, which is still quite expensive.
Advice to Management_x: Treat your hourly employees with dignity, as was done in the Rick-and-Larry-era, and the guests will return. People dine out for the experience as much as the food, and unhappy staff leads to unhappy guests.

Title_x: "25 years in Hospitality Industry, this is the worst company I've ever worked for."

Cons_x: Management's only concern is number crunching. Managers' style is consistently pessimistic. There was never a positive word of encouragement. The more an employee gave, the more was expected. Never a "thank you", never a "good job!"

Title_x: "Well run company with lots of opportunity for advancement."
Pros_x: Great good, great benefits, lots of opportunity for career growth
Cons_x: Horrible work life balance if you're in management. Working 60hrs a week is a common and expected thing.
Advice to Management_x: Find a way to have more work life balance or managers will keep leaving. Allow us to have more staffing because if we want to be the best in the industry, it takes more people to do it.

Cons_y: Horrible work life balance if you're in management. Working 60hrs a week is a common and expected thing.
Advice to Management_y: Find a way to have more work life balance or managers will keep leaving. Allow us to have more staffing because if we want to be the best in the industry, it takes more people to do it.

Pros_x: Great co workers,they made the job Barrable. Free food during training time. Big food discounts.
Cons_x: Management suck,VERY understaffed. Double shifts, no breaks. They don't care about servers.
Advice to Management_x: Stop talking to your servers like crap.

Pros_x: A company that genuinely cares about its people, product, and brand awareness. Lots of opportunities to grow within the company and because it is currently undergoing massive expansion, there are lots of chances to get into the new restaurants on the ground level. Great benefit packages.
Cons_x: As a restaurant manager (much like at most other restaurants), there are long hours and no set 9-5 schedule. Weekends are a must and time off is often difficult to accommodate.
Advice to Management_x: Keep the focus on the people. This company has great, loyal people who have worked hard for this company for many years. They are very deserving of the kind treatment that has always been a focus in the ROCK philosophy.

Pros_x: Flexible Hours, Friendly Managers, Easy Going Environment, Casual Uniform, Gain customer service knowledge
Cons_x: Not enough hours, Co-Workers often times are out for thier own benefit, Weekdays are dead, Training is shoddy, Lazy co-workers, Serving parties of kids (no tips)
Advice to Management_x: Show new servers how to be perform thier job, Be on the floor more often, Make a decent break room

Pros_x: None anymore. The food is alright?
Cons_x: Regional managers have put into place stringent standards a server has no control over (table turn time, e-mail sign up quotas) that if we can't meet then we lose shifts. Store level managers are useless. 4 table sections even on a slow monday lunch. Used to be such an amazing company to work for and the HR departments wants nothing to do with us as employees.
Advice to Management_x: Listen to your servers and stop applying across-the-board policies to every location. A business degree doesn't teach you street smarts.

Pros_x: There's a steady clientele, and most people are pretty familiar with the brand so there's a level of confidence in the products that's helpful. Most FOH employees work part time so if you need a specific day off there's usually someone who's willing to take your shift and help you out. If you work more than a certain number of hours per year, you get a bonus on your hiring anniversary. If you want to advance, the company makes that pretty easy. They like to promote from within when possible.
Cons_x: It's a corporate chain, so they have rules and regulations out the ying-yang. There's not a lot of flexibility when it comes to most things, and that isn't going to change no matter how much the employees might want it to. And since they're in the business of making money, a lot of those rules and regulations are to the detriment of their employees. Don't ever forget that you're replaceable. Part of the problem here is that the rules and regulations come from the corporate office, and 90% of the rule makers haven't worked a shift in years.

Cons_x: manager scheduling creates poor quality of life

Pros_y: many great benefits and coworkers
Cons_y: manager scheduling creates poor quality of life

Pros_x: Easy going, relaxed atmosphere. Good money when busy and depending on the location. My particular location has a great work atmosphere amongst the servers. One of the reasons I stayed for so long.
Cons_x: Change in management is changing the quality of service and overall happiness of the staff. While I understand that as a new manager/gm it is an adjustment, some if the changes are nit-picky and unnecessary. Some things instituted by the new management has made servers worried for their job. Another issue is the over staffing of weekends. A three table section is not enough to sustain a person who serves soley. Hence on lookout of another job.
Advice to Management_x: CPK never has a daily special. While we try to be above T.G.I. Friday tier, drink specials would draw in a daily crowd and drive up sales.

Cons_y: manager scheduling creates poor quality of life
Advice to Management_y: create permanent or rotating schedules to improve quality of life

Pros_x: Flexible hours/schedule. Chill people. Busy but manageable. Good experience if you are just starting out in the food industry. People are mostly helpful
Cons_x: Managment. Management is horrible, no organization or consistency. Every manager tells you something different. Gm is never there and usually has nothing but negative things to say even though he's not around to see you perform. Lazy managers. They are what make the job horrible and unenjoyable. If management can get their stuff together it'd be a better place to work.
Advice to Management_x: Value your employees and treat them well.. Communicate with other managers and us and provide consistency and be understanding of what we are dealing with instead of just trying to just get rid of the issue by agreeing with the customer.
Pros_y: many great benefits and coworkers
Cons_y: manager scheduling creates poor quality of life
Advice to Management_y: create permanent or rotating schedules to improve quality of life

Pros_x: ANYONE can be a server. It is the perfect way to make quick money without having to work ridiculous hours-especially while in school. CPK had a very fun work environment that was laid back for the most part. Once better management took over, everything improved drastically. There is no longer an extensive sequence of service that needs to be followed (there was in previous years, but it was thrown out). If you are an outgoing and fun person, this job is a breeze.
Cons_x: Things can be a bit stressful when the restaurant is busy, but every job can be stressful at times. It's easy to leave work at work.
Advice to Management_x: Keep it up! My managers were great leaders and friends.

Pros_x: CPK has a fun, laid back atmosphere for the most part. Hours are pretty flexible when there is a full staff of servers; most people are understanding and willing to swap shifts if something comes up. Management knows their jobs and cares for everyone under them, from cooks to hosts. Managers will help to make us as much money as possible, from running food to calming down customers. That in turn helps us to give each and every customer a positive experience. Pay for the amount of hours worked is AMAZING compared to every other serving job I've had. Overall: workers that care about one another like a family and do things together outside of work, great pay, and flexible hours (which is perfect for someone like me putting themselves through college)
Cons_x: One of my biggest complaints is Pizza Dough sign ups. We are told that we need to reach X amount of Pizza Dough sign ups each shift and that it is part of our job to sell this to customers. While I understand that it's to convince customers to want to come back, I feel like we are having to berate these customers. From what I understand, if we continuously do not hit our quota, we will have to go to meetings on how to sell this. If this fails, they would let us go. Plan to work most holidays (not just exclusive to CPK, however).
Advice to Management_x: While I understand that Pizza Dough gives to the guests, the way in which we are made to push them on the guests makes me a bit bitter about it.
Pros_y: many great benefits and coworkers
Cons_y: manager scheduling creates poor quality of life
Advice to Management_y: create permanent or rotating schedules to improve quality of life
