Pros_x: Absolutely LOVE working in this place! The energy, culture and excitement surrounding the transformation of the company is exhilarating! Great teamwork, lots of fun and a ton of opportunities for innovation. The CEO is so awesome! He is always walking around, saying hi to people, walking in your office and sitting down having casual conversations. You forget he is running to whole company. He wants your opinion and cares about what is going on in your life. This place has everything I love, fun, food, culture and leaders who get it!
Cons_x: Location. It is located in Playa Vista so the traffic and drive is not fun. But it has been worth it so far!
Advice to Management_x: Keep doing what your doing - focus on the people and keep it fun!

Pros_x: If the store is one that generates a lot of sales, tips are good.
Cons_x: Things may have changed since it's been quite some time since I worked there, but when I was there, there were lots of management issues. The company had been in trouble for making workers work through lunch without pay and was forced to pay them back, the management was micromanaging much for for no reason and was setting quotas for selling their new products. There were also issues about long-time employees getting their hours cut.
Advice to Management_x: Don't micromanage as much. California Pizza Kitchen is supposed to have a "laid back" atmosphere and forcing servers to constantly "push" products at customers because they're trying to meet quotas creates a less comfortable work atmosphere and dining experience for customers instead of just letting the server make genuine suggestions.
Pros_y: many great benefits and coworkers
Cons_y: manager scheduling creates poor quality of life
Advice to Management_y: create permanent or rotating schedules to improve quality of life

Title_x: "Overall a pretty great company to work for"
Pros_x: They offer some nice benefits for you even as just a part-time employee.. Serving always allows a flexible schedule, but the company will also allow leaves of absence as needed, with a guarantee of a job once the leave is over as long as you communicate with your managers. Leaves of absence can be for a number things as expected including just a personal leave.
Cons_x: When you work for any corporate company, it will always be a little cut-throat at times.
Advice to Management_x: This is not to the company as a whole, but to some managers in general, don't take your anger or frustrations out on your employees. They are working their little tails off to ensure as smooth a service as possible. Try to relax sometimes :)

Pros_x: Benefits include cheap(er) food, the benefits are just about as standard as you can expect.
Cons_x: You can find yourself fighting for hours, even if you're promised a full-time position. The management doesn't seem to know what to do with reservists when they are called away for service. I came back after two weeks and started getting only part-time hours; ended up just quitting after less than six months.

Pros_x: They hired me although I had no previous work experience. They trained me well. My hours were flexible, and I was asked to pick up shifts too which mean extra money.
Cons_x: Except for a few, a lot of my coworkers weren't that nice. I called it the Catty People Kitchen. Made a lot of inappropriate jokes because I was under 18 at the time and friends with one of the older waiters.
Advice to Management_x: Try to get the staff to integrate itself better and work together better. I was not really encouraged to get to know the waiters and kitchen staff and it felt kind of segregated.

Advice to Management_x: Make sure you hire managers who know what they are doing.

Advice to Management_x: Get rid of the rewards program, remove the kids menu so that the demographic of diners changes from families with their horde of kids, to families with grown up kids.
Pros_y: Good pay, good bonus structure.
Cons_y: They could care less about their people, only the bottom line. Expect to work 60+ hours every week. Upper management doesn't care about the quality of your life.
Advice to Management_y: Treat your people well or you will continue to lose good employees.

Pros_x: Fast paced, enjoyable co-workers, good table-waiting experience. Good tips and lively atmosphere! Good food too! I learned a lot from co-workers who had been working there for over two decades. Overall good customers too.
Cons_x: Took about a month to start working, training was relatively limited. Whenever the corporate office comes in, everything slows down exponentially because they are incredibly particular about specific protocol.
Advice to Management_x: Overall good. Scheduling should somehow be improved.

Pros_x: I absolutely love my co-workers; they are my family. They've revamped the training processes for new hires. There's room to move around and up in the company if you chat with management.
Cons_x: I hate the corporate structure that doesn't flex with each store; what works at one store may not in another. Because it's not privately owned, the customer is always right so we always look like the bad guy. And as with every customer service job, you'll just get "those" people.
Advice to Management_x: Listen to your employees. We may see/hear/do things you don't see if you don't get out of the office. We may have valuable suggestions. Don't be hypocritical.

Pros_x: The people that I worked with were the reason I loved coming to work. I also really liked a couple of my managers, they were very helpful and respectful of the staff and usually did whatever they could to help us out.
Cons_x: Getting to transition from a hostess or take out position was way too difficult. I had to constantly keep taking quizzes and getting certifications and then they would need someone to work as a host or on take out and I wouldn't get the chance to be a server and make more money.
Advice to Management_x: If an employee is qualified to move up, don't keep forcing them to work in their old position when they clearly express their desire to be a server.

Pros_x: Great for people who just start serving, with no experience necessary in some locations. Fun environment, delicious smells. The training for the part-time job is really long and you must do mandatory shadowing of more experienced servers, which was very helpful when first starting out.
Cons_x: Only a small employee discount (20% I believe). The management is undedicated and often unkind. Horrible hours-- weekends and nights, with rare days off for the holidays. Had to work all of the 4th of July.
Advice to Management_x: Be kinder to your employees, especially the ones just starting out! Work on your scheduling problems too and hire more people when you need it...

Pros_x: CPK was a good restaurant.
Cons_x: The restaurant is so corporate and they switch managers across locations at whim, so if you get to know and like the management, it can change in an instant. The move up potential is low as well. Although they say they promote hostesses and take-out employees to take out employees and servers respectively, it rarely happens and when it does, it takes a disgusting amount of time.. . Also, like many kitchens, there is a huge issue of sexual harassment. Managers see it and say nothing and it's not easy to complain in that kind of environment.
Advice to Management_x: If you want your restaurant not to feel like a chain restaurant, stop acting like a chain restaurant. By transferring managers so quickly, you destroy relationships and trust. Deal with your employees and stop sexual harassment when you see it, not just when people complain.

Title_x: "Pay isn't as great for a living"
Pros_x: -At first the employer was nice about treating you food after shifts, but then they got very cheap, they charge u a lot more than before, but it's still cheaper than original price.. -i had some very easy going coworkers.
Cons_x: As a host, every job positions including customers pretty much take their anger on you when it is busy. Customers are mad at you for giving them the "wrong quoted time", and bug u to sit on the dirty but empty table (well im sorry that i cant predict others getting up from their table and we cant shoo them away), servers will get mad when it's busy and u double seat them, bussers get mad at you for seating customers who rush u to seat them when tables are clean, kitchen asks you to slow down on seating people because they can't do all the order at the same time, managers help sometimes but not so much.
Advice to Management_x: i understand managers have lots on their mind, but there are some managers who dont seem to really care about employees but i feel like when there are trouble customers coming, they should reserve the right to serve them.

Pros_x: Decent people to work with (besides management)
Cons_x: This restaurant has gone down hill the past few years. Corporate restaurants are not the place to be. Management doesn't take anyone seriously or their ideas. They also laugh when we make serious suggestions. Very bad communication. Also, they may be running their restaurant illegally and underpaying most staff members! Run..
Advice to Management_x: Listen to your employees! We are one on one with "guests" every day.

Pros_x: Great food, easy to pick up and release shifts. Great company.
Cons_x: Management is obvious about favoritism, if you're not one of those select then expect a very small section.. Management will promise guests certain things, not communicate them to you and become frustrated if you make them follow through.. Corporate restrictions on section sizes will mean you make less money. They also put every server on during the weekend nights, which also means very little money.. It's a great first job to get experience, but nothing more.
Advice to Management_x: Realize what a great company you work for and act accordingly.

Pros_x: California pizza kitchen had Intense but efficient training sessions. And some of their employees were very passionate and excited about teaching the menu items.
Cons_x: The restaurant location I worked for did not run smoothly as it was a new location. The menu is also ridiculously huge. There are so many ingredients and things to learn and know about that is difficult to feel competent after only a week or so of training.
Advice to Management_x: Servers were hired based on personality - not experience. In some situations that might have been a good tactic- such as bringing new servers into an old location. But it is nearly impossible to start off a restaurant successfully with servers who have little or no experience. Management, finding a balance is a hard thing- but definitely something that needs to be achieved for success.
Pros_y: Great benefits, good bonus plan
Cons_y: Not reliable do not follow up on issues with management.
Advice to Management_y: When employees have issues including managers, they should do a complete investigation and follow through. There is more than just one sided views.GM's are not always truthful or ethical in the restarauants.

Pros_x: You get 50% of the whole menu, flexible scheduling.
Cons_x: Where does one begin... Not only is there a sexist manager, but the general manager does nothing to stop it. When you walk in to start your shift, there is absolutely nothing restocked so you have to spend the first two hours making boxes and filling everything up while taking care of 10 orders at the same time. Once I had to host and takeout and I did not receive the tips for hosting. Then I let the general manager know I no onger wanted to work in those conditions and that I rather work as a server and in return he stopped putting me on the schedule. The GENERAL MANAGER GOES OUT DRINKING WITH THE SERVERS, AND HAS FAVORITES, IF YOU'RE NOT A FAVORITE YOU WILL PROBABLY BE FIRED IN NO TIME.
Advice to Management_x: Listen to your employees when they have complains, and not bond over it while drinking a beer and popping peanuts in your mouth...
Pros_y: Great benefits, good bonus plan
Cons_y: Not reliable do not follow up on issues with management.
Advice to Management_y: When employees have issues including managers, they should do a complete investigation and follow through. There is more than just one sided views.GM's are not always truthful or ethical in the restarauants.

Pros_x: great culture from the home office
Cons_x: lots of hours, usually 60 or more. Company has been down in sales for many years, starting to turn around but recovery has been costly and slow. Like any job it depends on your boss.
Pros_y: great culture from the home office
Cons_y: lots of hours, usually 60 or more. Company has been down in sales for many years, starting to turn around but recovery has been costly and slow. Like any job it depends on your boss.

Pros_x: The company offers great benefits to its managers. They have a great training program, but you must be self motivated. The food is excellent.
Cons_x: They don't recognize the good in everyone. The 50 hour work week is unrealistic when you don't have support from upper management on a 3 man team. They make up the rules as they go, and it doesn't apply to everyone.

Pros_x: Quick money, flexible. Friendly when they choose to be. Great customers. Easy to move up/around (bar training, closing shifts).
Cons_x: Unprofessional staff, inconsistent objectives/rules, favor towards certain employees. Employees may be aggressive towards new hires if they aren't making the money they want. Pulled off the schedule without warning as consequence but notified of write-ups.
Advice to Management_x: Try to be consistent, less intimidating to staff and keep confidential matters confidential. Management hanging out with new hires alone for drinks is not okay. Coming to work intoxicated should stop.

Pros_x: You get free food sometimes and its a pretty social and fun environment.
Cons_x: My manager was always making fun of me which was really annoying because I am a perfectly capable employee. Additionally, you have to do all these things like roll silverware and clean after your shift but you're only making $2 an hour plus tips so during this time you are working your butt off and only making $2 and hour because you don't even have any tables.
Advice to Management_x: Provide better training and pay the bussers with company money. Don't use server tips to pay the hosts and bussers. Your servers are working super hard to try and make more than $2 an hour so they should probably be allowed to keep all of their tips.

Cons_y: They don't recognize the good in everyone. The 50 hour work week is unrealistic when you don't have support from upper management on a 3 man team. They make up the rules as they go, and it doesn't apply to everyone.

Pros_x: This place was wonderful until it was bought by a different company. Used to offer so many perks and great pay. Pros_x: - Flexible schedules. (Mobile app is available to see work schedules and/or make requests off.). - Relaxed management/work environment for the most part.. - Great co-workers, very hospitable environment, and decent client base.. - No serving experience necessary to get hired.. - Server side work is very easy compared to other chain restaurants.. - Food and drink menus are easy to learn.. - Excellent for making quick cash.. - Working shifts normally consist of 4 hours.. - Can cross train into any position.. - Yearly bonuses ($350) are paid to full time employees.
Cons_x: - Rewards sign-ups are mandatory and no compensation is paid regardless of the amount.. - Management will purposely understaff in order to cut labor costs and will also send cooks home early, leaving only one in charge of four separate stations. Tipped employees pay the price for it.. - Only one bartender is scheduled per shift and are given way too much responsibility. They are required to not only bartend and wait tables but to also work at take-out which is a separate job (due to the high volume of orders that always come in) and to also man the expo (the cooks job to manage food going out) which is another separate job. It affects the bartenders tips.. - No barbacks are ever hired and take-out positions are only filled 4 shifts out of 14 shifts in order to cut labor costs.. - Again, in order to cut labor costs, they make the busser do the dishwashers job for the same buss boy pay.. - They are incredibly quick to hire and overstaff hosts/hostesses compared to every other position combined.. - No career advancement or opportunities offered.
Advice to Management_x: - Put employees before profit.. - Expand employee benefits and make them be known.. - Speed of service and customer satisfaction can drastically improve if the company stops being so cheap when it comes to labor costs.
Pros_y: The Culture is great, the people are awesome. The Direction of the company is positive. The Changes the company has made have fallen into place nicely.
Cons_y: The Salary is low for tenure. Raises happen infrequently. Bonus structure tough to beat with some circumstances out of control.
Advice to Management_y: None

Cons_x: Paid on hourly basis and it is hard to put in a lot of hours since you are basically going out in the world and trying to bring new business to California Pizza Kitchen. I was never reimbursed for gas which was a little aggravating.
Advice to Management_x: Overall great guidance and very helpful for support.

Pros_x: The company treats you wonderfully, friendly, fun atmosphere. Bosses are easily approachable
Cons_x: Terrible pay. I live in a town where we have "seasons". During season is when it is busy and "off season" is painfully slow. As a hostess I make $6.30 an hour plus tips. When it is not season, I only make around 8-13 dollars a night in tips at the best.
Advice to Management_x: Raise the pay for hostesses! They make only a dollar more than the servers and barely any tips. Barely break even commuting to work.

Pros_x: Not too hard of a job. You just have to be able to multi task and stay positive even when a customer is completely disrespectful. Positive environment. Willing to try to work with schedule. Great tips!!!
Cons_x: Politics. Drama in between coworkers. No such thing as a raise or way to get more hours opportunities if there are a lot of hosts. Not aloud to eat mistake food haha.

Pros_x: California Pizza Kitchen is a fast paced work environment. It takes a lot memorization and organization. I have 5 different job codes and work in all 5 areas each week. I have knowledge in every field in the location I am currently in. I get a lot of face time with customers as well as partners for fundraisers and catering. I deal with my employees and their customers on a daily basis. It is a wonderful stepping stone that helps shape my future.
Cons_x: I am still an hourly, part-time employee. Because I have so many job codes, I am always at a different pay rate. My paychecks are never the same and neither are my hours or my schedule. I work 7 days a week every week at a part-time, hourly pay. I am never compensated for my overtime hours as well as I wasn't being paid for over two months for my brand ambassador. I was promised bonuses and pay for my ROI and after I had the best ROI for fundraisers are catering in the region, I did not receive even a thank you. I am asked to work every day off I have and when I ask for a day off I am guilt tripped into working more.
Advice to Management_x: I am just a part time employee who is at the location more than most of the managers. I do not get paid for all of my work and I am constantly guilt tripped into doing things that I have not been trained for.
Pros_y: The Culture is great, the people are awesome. The Direction of the company is positive. The Changes the company has made have fallen into place nicely.
Cons_y: The Salary is low for tenure. Raises happen infrequently. Bonus structure tough to beat with some circumstances out of control.
Advice to Management_y: None

Pros_x: Meeting other servers, bartenders, hosts. They hired a really great bunch of people.
Cons_x: Management. They drink on the job, are unapproachable, blame the staff for anything and everything, break their own contract rules (no eating upstairs but they eat upstairs), they didnt pay us for the first 4 weeks we worked there, they dont pay their accounts for their bar suppliers so were always out of stuff, dont give proper training cuz they dont know what they're doing themselves but will be the first to blame all the other staff, dont support their staff in any way possible or give them any benefits (not even free food after making them work long hours), for the first 3 weeks of opening nobody got any breaks.
Advice to Management_x: Don't open up the second store just because your contract says you have to when you cant even handle one store

Title_x: "If employees were treated as well as customers, this job would be awesome"
Pros_x: -free meals during training. -free sodas. -they teach you how to upsell. -if you're good at up selling, you can make okay tips in a night. -50 percent off employee meals
Cons_x: -Training is a long process. It's paid, but it's tedious. There are written tests and multiple shadow shifts.. -Our restaurant staffs way too many employees at times when they're not needed and as such, it's difficult for us to pay our bills.. -The High 5 Hospitality (sort of like a fancy code of fun rules) says on rule #2 that CPK wants you to be who you (really) are. And yes, the word "really" is in parentheses. The problem is that this only applies to some people. Tattoos are okay, crazy colored hair is okay, but piercings are not. This is hypocritical. It allows some people to be who they (really) are and not others. And it mostly sucks that some of the other servers get to have the physical modifications that make them who they really are, but not all of us. Plus, that damn rule is shoved in our faces repeatedly during training and it's on the wall, so it feels like a smack in the face. I'm a more confident and pleasant server when I feel confident about who I am-and part of that confidence comes from my appearance.. -I've been serving for a couple of years now, and I feel confident in my abilities. However, CPK has a lot of items and modifiers on the menu and in the Aloha computer system, and even for someone with serving experience and experience with Aloha, it takes some time to adjust to a new restaurant. On my first solo shift, I was giving a 5 top on a busy night. As expected, I wasn't able to keep up so well. At the end of the night, I asked to only have 4 tops for just a short while and the on shift manager happily agreed. I've had two more solo shifts since and I've had 5 tops both nights. For a company so focused on customer service and service details, there's a huge lack of awareness of what's possible for a newbie to the restaurant to even do.
Advice to Management_x: If employees were treated as well as customers, this job would be awesome. It's too difficult to pay my bills with this job-even if I get tipped 20 percent with every bill. There are too many employees scheduled at a time and it's costing all of us money. We're all hurting financially. I'm still very new at this job and even with serving experience, it's crazy to give my a 5 top on my first solo shift. That makes no sense! For a company so utterly focused on top notch customer service, it must be clear that it's nearly impossible for a new hire to serve 5 tables on a busy night with great service details and a smile. A person needs at least a shift or two to adjust to four tables.. . Also, the High 5 Hospitality is hypocritical. I'm sorry to say it, but it is. #2 on the list says that CPK wants employees to be who we (really) are. But this seems to only apply to some people. Tattoos are okay (some tattoos), crazy colored hair is okay, but piercings are not. This is hypocritical. It allows some people to be who they (really) are and not others. And it feels terrible that some of the other servers get to have the physical modifications that make them feel confident about who they really are, but not all of us get to have that. Plus, that rule is everywhere (on the walls, on the tests, etc.), so it's impossible to ignore. I'm a more confident and pleasant server when I feel confident about who I am-and part of that is my appearance. As long as my hygiene is good, I should be allowed to be who I really am, right?
Pros_y: The Culture is great, the people are awesome. The Direction of the company is positive. The Changes the company has made have fallen into place nicely.
Cons_y: The Salary is low for tenure. Raises happen infrequently. Bonus structure tough to beat with some circumstances out of control.
Advice to Management_y: None

Employee Title_x: Hospitality Manager, Director of Marketing, Head of Training
Pros_x: Great management, friendly staff, flexible hours and schedules. They try to promote from within when possible. Extremely high cleanliness and health standards.
Cons_x: None that I can think of currently. As a server, host, busser, cook, etc. you're not going to make a ridiculous amount of money; you make a typical amount for the industry. You also don't qualify for benefits unless you consistently work a high number of hours.

Cons_y: None that I can think of currently. As a server, host, busser, cook, etc. you're not going to make a ridiculous amount of money; you make a typical amount for the industry. You also don't qualify for benefits unless you consistently work a high number of hours.

Employee Title_y: Hospitality Manager, Director of Marketing, Head of Training
Pros_y: Great management, friendly staff, flexible hours and schedules. They try to promote from within when possible. Extremely high cleanliness and health standards.

Pros_x: I have served many places and this is by far the easiest amount of work for the most amount of money. As a server I have used tip bucket and normally average 18-20 in tips per hour for each month. It's easy picking up and giving up shifts. They schedule based on performance and very little politics when giving sections. There are a few employees who do get whatever they want but they have been there for 5 plus years. Basic employee discounts and benefits. Seems like they are trying to sell the company again so that means they are raising prices and taking off menu items that make us different from other pizza places.
Cons_x: Small restaurant and annoying when you have to work with a lot of people on the weekends. The company acts like it has culture but it doesn't. They think remodeling the store creates a laid back California atmosphere but they cram as many tables in the dining room as they can and its a tight fit making everyone uncomfortable. They are clearly looking for profits. The company was in the red for like 8 years and finally have been green due to increased menu prices year after year however customer count has gone down. Wonder why?!? They take all the good stuff off the menu so they can cut corners on ordering and prepping labor. Brandon mall closed because the mall wouldn't renew their lease because they themselves saw it was so slow.
Advice to Management_x: Stop taking short cuts. If your about the guest experience don't just comp food, but hold servers and management responsible for their experience and stop putting lame general managers in charge. Give them back to texas roadhouse and take GJ too!

Cons_x: One of the managers in my description is nice one minute and then doesn't care the next he is lazy. I won't give names or what they look like .

Pros_x: Comprehensive Server training program for two-weeks prior to serving customers. Required to pass a role play server scenario with management acting as customers. Will need to know the menu well and the upsells prior to serving customers. Typically hire a good team a people.
Cons_x: Command and control management style at this particular CPK I worked at. Uneven distribution of income producing table sections for servers. Strong cultural division between the Back-of-the-House and the Front-of-the-house due to language barriers. Strong division between management and employees. Went through three manager changes over a course of one year.
Advice to Management_x: Train your Managers in leadership, coaching, culture building and empathy, not just process control and making the numbers. Work on growth development of your BOH employees, particularly with language skills in the industry. Create an exit interview process to gain valuable information why your employees are leaving. Limit the amount of Manager changes in one year.

Pros_x: Outstanding Management. Free food. Great teamwork. Prize incentives
Cons_x: Minimum wage. No free parking at some locations. A lot of no-shows. End up working by yourself. Sucks but its possible, even on a heavy night.

Pros_y: Great management, friendly staff, flexible hours and schedules. They try to promote from within when possible. Extremely high cleanliness and health standards.
Cons_y: None that I can think of currently. As a server, host, busser, cook, etc. you're not going to make a ridiculous amount of money; you make a typical amount for the industry. You also don't qualify for benefits unless you consistently work a high number of hours.

Pros_y: Great management, friendly staff, flexible hours and schedules. They try to promote from within when possible. Extremely high cleanliness and health standards.
Cons_y: None that I can think of currently. As a server, host, busser, cook, etc. you're not going to make a ridiculous amount of money; you make a typical amount for the industry. You also don't qualify for benefits unless you consistently work a high number of hours.

Pros_x: Encourage individuality (tattoos, piercings, hairstyles). Youthful coworkers if you're a server.. Delicious food.. Flexible scheduling.
Cons_x: Attracts tourists (bad tippers) and older people (demanding, bad tippers).. Forced to promote the Rewards Program.. Food still expensive even with 50% employee discount.. Business fluctuates dramatically during the year.

Title_x: "Great company but will depend on your location and management team."
Pros_x: California state of mind atmosphere.. Pretty laid back job for the most part.. Decent money especially around holidays.. Flexible scheduling.
Cons_x: Managers often just stand around on their phones complaining about the staff which results in very low morale among employees.. Hard work frequently goes unnoticed so there is no motivation to try and stand out.. Lazy managers - you can tell they only care about numbers so they can make their bonus.. Too much miscommunication and disagreement between managers. Makes them look weak to the staff.. Kitchen manager makes everybody hate their lives while at work and does nothing to try and improve himself.. They pay very little and expect a lot but never lead by example.
Advice to Management_x: Make sure your managers all get along before hiring a new one. Send in secret shoppers more to observe the dynamics of the restaurant because anyone can pretend to pull it together when corporate is in town. Motivate your employees with encouragement and optimism, NOT harassment and pessimism.

Pros_x: People that work there are sweet, the pizza isn't bad, kitchen keeps low ticket times, rotating tap selection is actually good.
Cons_x: Micromanagement, scheduling issues, for most of the staff it's their first job in the industry so sections are tiny and people freak out, very limited bar almost like a hotel bar. No matter your experience you have to train over a week to even be able to use a jigger.
Advice to Management_x: Get scheduling right, fix training schedule and train for more than 4 table sections, if you want a bartender make it a real bar, stop hiding in the office when it's busier or stop hovering over one person when just running food would fix other people.
Pros_y: Good pay. Good benefits, career growth
Cons_y: Long shifts, 50-60 hrs week. Work nights, weekends and holidays.
Advice to Management_y: Its a Hard work but you like what you are doing you can have the opportunity of career growth

Title_x: "Was a fine place to work as a starter, really looking forward to something else now"
Pros_x: Really good food (free fountain drinks and bread, food at half-price to employees), great coworkers (the servers, not the hosts I worked with), slightly above average paycheck when including cuts for tips. Really nice managers. Ideal for students.
Cons_x: Was promised numerous times I would be considered for higher positions, never even received opportunities to even attempt to gain those positions, nor did any of my other coworkers in the same position. Hosting was extremely monotonous, immediate co-hosts were nice but didn't seem to enjoy talking to me whenever I tried to engage in conversation, was very bored most of the time.
Advice to Management_x: If someone wants to be a server, asks multiple times about it, and works at the location for nearly two years, the least you can do is at least tell that person no, it's not going to happen, rather than beat around the bush with the vague promise that something might come up soon when it never does. Felt somewhat cheated and used up by the end of it.
Pros_y: Good pay. Good benefits, career growth
Cons_y: Long shifts, 50-60 hrs week. Work nights, weekends and holidays.
Advice to Management_y: Its a Hard work but you like what you are doing you can have the opportunity of career growth

Title_x: "Extremely fun, uplifting, and taught me a lot"
Pros_x: Amazing people, everyone is family and helps coworkers when they really need it. Uniforms are not horrible either. 50% off food right after or before a shift
Cons_x: Managers treat costumer's better then staff, pick favorites and it seems that CPK has a rather nasty costumer base. Really slow shifts
Advice to Management_x: The costumer should have a good experience for sure, but it shouldn't hurt your servers

Title_x: "Driver for another company which i was eorking"
Pros_x: Please everyone read very careul this a real story just happen this nov 2017
Cons_x: I had bad experience being a driver than being taking off my job because of a mistake someone made from California kitchen pizza
Advice to Management_x: I was a delivering driver for past 2 yrs.after picking up a order from california kitchen pizza located burbank ca.i had bad experience i arrived i waited over 30 minutes for my order.after one of the employed gave copy of my receipt he ask me back for my copy he didnt have his own copy i asked dont u have a copy machine he said yes but he didnt know how to operate it.soones i handle my copy he started giving my order name by name each item was label with customer name .after after he said my order was complete.ihe was marking each item in my receipt.after he told was totally complete.i left to drop off client food .after arriving i was missing 1 small item than i made a phone over to his manager to explain what happen.minutes or hr after i get cant log in my app. To work next day .i was been told by my corporation that manager of california kirchen puzza had giving a story about me telling him that he need it to reimburse $$$ if i need to go back and recover what ever item i was missing .i never said that .so they took me off my schedule for someone else making a mistake.lost my morning job.but thank you to manager at this location in burbank ca
Pros_y: Good pay. Good benefits, career growth
Cons_y: Long shifts, 50-60 hrs week. Work nights, weekends and holidays.
Advice to Management_y: Its a Hard work but you like what you are doing you can have the opportunity of career growth

Pros_x: Depends on location. I worked at one location where the management was more helpful and better than another location, or the clientele was better. Opportunity to move up and learn new positions pretty quickly. Probably better culture than most restaurants.
Cons_x: Again, depends on location. Managers were not as good in one location I worked and not as helpful. At one point, GM was trying to make it so the employees felt like they could let more of their personality show with uniform changes, no scripts, etc. However, they just went back to a lot of the same rules less than a year later, which means I had to buy all new shirts again. Only stayed for so long because of the people I worked with and I knew all of the food. Most hourly don't qualify for good benefits.
Advice to Management_x: When you implement new uniform and procedures to promote a more casual vibe and letting the servers' personality show through more, don't just revert back less than a year later. We had to buy all new shirts each time, and felt like nothing really changed in procedures. Need better benefits. Most hourly don't qualify for the full-time benefits, and the part-time benefits aren't worth it.
Pros_y: Good pay. Good benefits, career growth
Cons_y: Long shifts, 50-60 hrs week. Work nights, weekends and holidays.
Advice to Management_y: Its a Hard work but you like what you are doing you can have the opportunity of career growth
